column1: Their only other option was to let Tyler Ulis cook. I think they made the right choice

No... A lot of non-point guards score in a very on-ball manner. KD is one such player. Grab the ball at the top of the 3pt line and let him cook. CJ McCollum is another example. Tyler Herro isn't like that. He catches the ball and makes his attack immediately upon the catch or he passes it off. He needs the ball delivered to him in spots he's comfortable playmaking from.

I think the reason we're interested is bc we have 3 backend roster spots open as of today. We had 3 10-day contracts expiring this weekend.   So yes, ideally we'd love an athletic big, but the real way Sean Marks is looking at it is... would you rather have Blake Griffin or Iman Shumpert? BG or Andre Roberson? BG or Tyler Cook?   So whether he'll get minutes, will be a topic of discussion, but having him on the roster over those other 3 seems like a no brainer.

at 1:18 in the video, standard entry bounce pass into the post, Cook just doesn't catch it. Nothing wrong with the pass.  at 1:28, Tyler Cook calls for the lob and can't finish. Good defensive play by OKC, but Cook probably should finish that one. Chalk it up to good defense.  at 3:37, not a great pass from Cade there, too low for a big man, but it still could have been handled. This one's on Cade.  at 4:05 lofts it up there for Cook nice and soft, and Cook forgets he has hands. Probably not high enough for the oop but still should be an easy basket 9/10 times. Easy dunk or layup that instead was a turnover.  at 4:13 Cade leads Cook in transition on the run with a bounce pass about as well as you can, and Cook can't come up with it cleanly. Had an open lane for a dunk or likely would have been grabbed and fouled.

Heat are going to go to the finals again:  1. They have one of the deepest teams  2. Tyler Herro is going to cook bench units alive  3. Kyle Lowry will bring much needed play making.  4. Bam should have taken a huge step forward.  5. Overall, they have no major weaknesses and can match up with anyone in the East.

I'm 6'6" and purely in strength, I can hang with the average NBA player. But, when I was an upper classmen in high-school, and in the best shape of my life, and full of that teenager energy, and playing ball 5 or 6 days a week, a couple of prepubescent kids who would go on to play at USC and KState before making it to the NBA could cook me and all of my boys. Anybody who didn't play at least high-major ball that thinks that they have a shot at this feat in a competive scenario is out of their minds.   But, if I had somebody like Bird or LBJ to throw me an outlet on a cherry picker, I might be able to score a bucket. And maybe if I could lob it up from half court to like, Wilt or AD or somebody that could throw down even my high and wide pass, then there's an assist. The rebound would be easier for me than most, since I'm actually comparably tall to perimeter players, but it would still be about 99% luck. Even if I was matched up against Mugsy or like, Tyler Ulis, I wouldn't have much of a chance barring a perfect bounce. Still, I wouldn't say its impossible if your coach and teams goal was to get you your stats.

Lower usage Era buy not necessarily better defensively.  Today you have to cover all 5 positions as a player because most teams have 5 guys who can shoot.  Back then maybe 2 players on the floor at a time could shoot 3s and it's much lower volume.  Also heavy one on one defense equals lower efficiency .  Depends who Tyler has on his team.  The 2021 Heat would cook in that Era. But Tyler alone would probably struggle.
